AI.method: The paper surveys and explores approaches such as inverse reinforcement learning, preference-based reward modeling, and self-supervised intrinsic reward learning, and proposes to investigate new or combined methods to construct more reliable dense rewards across different RL applications.
AI.result: The abstract is a proposal, so it does not report empirical results; instead, it outlines intended research directions for improving dense reward construction in RL.
AI.conclusion: Improving the construction of dense reward functions—by leveraging IRL, human preference modeling, and intrinsic rewards—has the potential to make RL agents more efficient, robust, and better aligned with human intent, but key trade-offs in generality, scalability, and alignment remain open research problems.

title: ADAPT: Learning Task Mixtures for Budget-Constrained Instruction Tuning
summary: We propose ADAPT, a meta-learning algorithm that \emph{learns} task sampling proportions under an explicit token budget for multi-task instruction tuning. Instead of fixing task weights by hand, \adapt{} maintains a continuous distribution over tasks and updates it via meta-gradients of a smooth worst-case validation objective, inducing an adaptive curriculum that allocates more tokens to useful tasks while avoiding collapse. We instantiate ADAPT on three $\sim$1B-parameter open-weight LLMs (Gemma-3-1B, LLaMA-3.2-1B, Qwen-0.6B), training on 20 Natural Instructions task types under budgets of $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ of the available supervised tokens, and compare against strong supervised fine-tuning baselines with uniform and size-proportional mixing. We conduct evaluations on 11 out-of-domain benchmarks spanning reasoning, reading comprehension, code generation, and instruction following, we find that ADAPT matches or slightly improves average downstream performance relative to the best static mixture, while using fewer effective training tokens and reallocating budget toward harder, benchmark-aligned tasks.

AI.tldr: ADAPT is a meta-learning method that automatically learns how often to sample each task for multi-task instruction tuning under a fixed token budget, improving efficiency and performance over static task mixtures.
AI.motivation: In multi-task instruction tuning of LLMs, practitioners typically hand-design or heuristically fix task sampling proportions (e.g., uniform or size-proportional). This is suboptimal, especially under strict token or compute budgets, because some tasks are more beneficial for downstream performance than others. The authors aim to automatically discover an effective curriculum that allocates limited training tokens to the most useful tasks, avoids overfitting or collapse, and better aligns training with evaluation benchmarks.
AI.method: The authors introduce ADAPT, a meta-learning algorithm that maintains a continuous probability distribution over training tasks and updates this distribution using meta-gradients. The objective is a smooth worst-case validation loss over tasks, which encourages robustness and focuses on harder or more important tasks. Under an explicit global token budget, ADAPT adaptively adjusts task sampling proportions during training, effectively learning a curriculum. They apply ADAPT to three ~1B-parameter open-weight LLMs (Gemma-3-1B, LLaMA-3.2-1B, Qwen-0.6B), training on 20 Natural Instructions task types at different token budget levels (1%, 5%, 10% of available supervised tokens), and compare to fixed mixtures (uniform and size-proportional).
AI.result: Across 11 out-of-domain benchmarks covering reasoning, reading comprehension, code generation, and instruction following, ADAPT generally matches or slightly exceeds the performance of the best static task mixture. It does this while using fewer effective training tokens and automatically reallocating more of the budget toward harder tasks that are better aligned with evaluation benchmarks. This demonstrates that learned task sampling can be at least as effective as carefully chosen static mixtures while being more token-efficient.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that meta-learned task sampling under a token budget is a practical and effective strategy for multi-task instruction tuning. ADAPT can replace manual or heuristic task mixing with an automated procedure that yields competitive or improved downstream performance, better token efficiency, and an adaptive curriculum focused on challenging, benchmark-relevant tasks. This suggests that future instruction-tuned LLM training pipelines can benefit from integrating adaptive, validation-driven task sampling instead of relying on fixed mixtures.

title: LexGenius: An Expert-Level Benchmark for Large Language Models in Legal General Intelligence
summary: Legal general intelligence (GI) refers to artificial intelligence (AI) that encompasses legal understanding, reasoning, and decision-making, simulating the expertise of legal experts across domains. However, existing benchmarks are result-oriented and fail to systematically evaluate the legal intelligence of large language models (LLMs), hindering the development of legal GI. To address this, we propose LexGenius, an expert-level Chinese legal benchmark for evaluating legal GI in LLMs. It follows a Dimension-Task-Ability framework, covering seven dimensions, eleven tasks, and twenty abilities. We use the recent legal cases and exam questions to create multiple-choice questions with a combination of manual and LLM reviews to reduce data leakage risks, ensuring accuracy and reliability through multiple rounds of checks. We evaluate 12 state-of-the-art LLMs using LexGenius and conduct an in-depth analysis. We find significant disparities across legal intelligence abilities for LLMs, with even the best LLMs lagging behind human legal professionals. We believe LexGenius can assess the legal intelligence abilities of LLMs and enhance legal GI development. Our project is available at https://github.com/QwenQKing/LexGenius.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces LexGenius, a Chinese legal benchmark to systematically evaluate the legal general intelligence (GI) of large language models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: Existing legal AI benchmarks focus mainly on end results (e.g., accuracy on specific tasks) and do not systematically measure the breadth and depth of legal understanding, reasoning, and decision-making required for legal general intelligence. This limitation hinders diagnosing strengths and weaknesses of LLMs in law and slows progress toward expert-level legal AI.
AI.method: The authors design LexGenius, a benchmark following a Dimension-Task-Ability framework with 7 dimensions, 11 task types, and 20 specific abilities that together aim to characterize legal GI. They construct expert-level, multiple-choice questions in Chinese based on recent legal cases and exam questions. To minimize data leakage and ensure quality, they combine manual curation with LLM-based reviews and conduct multiple rounds of validation. They then evaluate 12 state-of-the-art LLMs on LexGenius and perform detailed comparative analysis across abilities and dimensions.
AI.result: The evaluated LLMs show large performance disparities across different legal abilities. Even the strongest current models still perform notably worse than human legal professionals on many parts of the benchmark, revealing substantial gaps in present-day legal GI.
AI.conclusion: LexGenius offers a structured, expert-level benchmark to systematically assess legal general intelligence in LLMs, revealing current limitations and variation across abilities. The authors argue that this benchmark can guide model development and evaluation in the legal domain, thereby advancing research toward more capable legal GI systems. The benchmark and related resources are released publicly on GitHub.

title: Efficient Reinforcement Learning with Semantic and Token Entropy for LLM Reasoning
summary: Reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) has demonstrated superior performance in enhancing the reasoning capability of large language models (LLMs). However, this accuracy-oriented learning paradigm often suffers from entropy collapse, which reduces policy exploration and limits reasoning capabilities. To address this challenge, we propose an efficient reinforcement learning framework that leverages entropy signals at both the semantic and token levels to improve reasoning. From the data perspective, we introduce semantic entropy-guided curriculum learning, organizing training data from low to high semantic entropy to guide progressive optimization from easier to more challenging tasks. For the algorithmic design, we adopt non-uniform token treatment by imposing KL regularization on low-entropy tokens that critically impact policy exploration and applying stronger constraints on high-covariance portions within these tokens. By jointly optimizing data organization and algorithmic design, our method effectively mitigates entropy collapse and enhances LLM reasoning. Experimental results across 6 benchmarks with 3 different parameter-scale base models demonstrate that our method outperforms other entropy-based approaches in improving reasoning.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a reinforcement learning framework that uses semantic- and token-level entropy signals to mitigate entropy collapse and improve reasoning in large language models.
AI.motivation: Existing RL with verifiable rewards (RLVR) improves LLM reasoning but tends to cause entropy collapse, reducing exploration and ultimately limiting reasoning performance. There is a need for a method that preserves or uses entropy more effectively to drive better reasoning during RL training.
AI.method: The authors design a two-part framework. (1) Data-side: semantic entropy-guided curriculum learning, where training examples are ordered from low to high semantic entropy so the model is optimized progressively from easier to harder reasoning tasks. Semantic entropy measures uncertainty at a higher, semantic level of the model’s outputs. (2) Algorithm-side: non-uniform token treatment via KL regularization. Low-entropy (confident) tokens that are important for exploration are regularized with a KL term, and within these, token segments with high covariance receive stronger constraints. This couples data organization with a tailored RL objective that accounts for entropy properties at different granularities.
AI.result: On 6 reasoning benchmarks and with 3 different LLM base sizes, the proposed approach achieves better reasoning performance than other entropy-based RL methods. The experiments indicate that the method successfully mitigates entropy collapse and yields more accurate and robust reasoning.
AI.conclusion: By jointly structuring the training data via semantic entropy-based curriculum learning and shaping the RL objective with token-level, non-uniform KL regularization, the proposed framework alleviates entropy collapse in RLVR and significantly enhances LLM reasoning across multiple benchmarks and model scales.

title: Geschlechtsübergreifende Maskulina im Sprachgebrauch Eine korpusbasierte Untersuchung zu lexemspezifischen Unterschieden
summary: This study examines the distribution and linguistic characteristics of generic masculines (GM) in contemporary German press texts. The use of masculine personal nouns to refer to mixed-gender groups or unspecified individuals has been widely debated in academia and the public, with con-flicting perspectives on its gender-neutrality. While psycholinguistic studies suggest that GM is more readily associated with male referents, corpus-based analyses of its actual use remain scarce. We investigate GM in a large corpus of press texts, focusing on lexeme-specific differences across dif-ferent types of personal nouns. We conducted manual annotations of the whole inflectional para-digm of 21 personal nouns, resulting in 6,195 annotated tokens. Our findings reveal considerable differences between lexical items, especially between passive role nouns and prestige-related per-sonal nouns. On a grammatical level, we find that GM occurs predominantly in the plural and in indefinite noun phrases. Furthermore, our data shows that GM is not primarily used to denote entire classes of people, as has been previously claimed. By providing an empirical insight into the use of GM in authentic written language, we contribute to a more nuanced understanding of its forms and manifestations. These findings provide a solid basis for aligning linguistic stimuli in psy-cholinguistic studies more closely with real-world language use.

AI.tldr: The paper empirically analyzes how generic masculine forms are actually used in contemporary German press texts, revealing lexeme-specific patterns and challenging the idea that they primarily denote whole classes of people.
AI.motivation: Debates in both academia and the public question whether generic masculines in German are truly gender-neutral. Psycholinguistic evidence suggests a male bias in their interpretation, but there is a lack of large-scale corpus-based studies on how they are used in real texts. The authors aim to fill this empirical gap and provide a realistic basis for experimental research.
AI.method: The authors compile a large corpus of contemporary German press texts and select 21 masculine personal nouns that can potentially function generically. They manually annotate the complete inflectional paradigm for these nouns within the corpus, resulting in 6,195 annotated tokens. They then analyze the distribution of generic vs. specific uses across lexemes and grammatical contexts (e.g., number, definiteness, type of noun such as passive role vs. prestige-related).
AI.result: The study finds strong lexeme-specific variation in how often masculine personal nouns are used generically. Passive role nouns and prestige-related personal nouns behave differently in their generic usage. Grammatically, generic masculine uses are most frequent in the plural and in indefinite noun phrases. Contrary to earlier claims, generic masculines are not primarily used to denote entire classes of people; their generic range is more restricted and context-dependent.
AI.conclusion: Generic masculines in German press texts cannot be treated as a uniform phenomenon: their usage depends heavily on the specific lexical item and grammatical context. The forms appear most often in plural and indefinite contexts and are less class-denoting than frequently assumed. These empirical findings refine our understanding of how generic masculines function in authentic written German and offer a more realistic foundation for designing and interpreting psycholinguistic experiments on gender representation in language.

title: AgentBay: A Hybrid Interaction Sandbox for Seamless Human-AI Intervention in Agentic Systems
summary: The rapid advancement of Large Language Models (LLMs) is catalyzing a shift towards autonomous AI Agents capable of executing complex, multi-step tasks. However, these agents remain brittle when faced with real-world exceptions, making Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) supervision essential for mission-critical applications. In this paper, we present AgentBay, a novel sandbox service designed from the ground up for hybrid interaction. AgentBay provides secure, isolated execution environments spanning Windows, Linux, Android, Web Browsers, and Code interpreters. Its core contribution is a unified session accessible via a hybrid control interface: An AI agent can interact programmatically via mainstream interfaces (MCP, Open Source SDK), while a human operator can, at any moment, seamlessly take over full manual control. This seamless intervention is enabled by Adaptive Streaming Protocol (ASP). Unlike traditional VNC/RDP, ASP is specifically engineered for this hybrid use case, delivering an ultra-low-latency, smoother user experience that remains resilient even in weak network environments. It achieves this by dynamically blending command-based and video-based streaming, adapting its encoding strategy based on network conditions and the current controller (AI or human). Our evaluation demonstrates strong results in security, performance, and task completion rates. In a benchmark of complex tasks, the AgentBay (Agent + Human) model achieved more than 48% success rate improvement. Furthermore, our ASP protocol reduces bandwidth consumption by up to 50% compared to standard RDP, and in end-to-end latency with around 5% reduction, especially under poor network conditions. We posit that AgentBay provides a foundational primitive for building the next generation of reliable, human-supervised autonomous systems.

AI.tldr: AgentBay is a sandbox + streaming system that lets AI agents and humans share and swap control of isolated execution environments with low latency and high robustness.
AI.motivation: LLM-based AI agents can perform complex tasks but are brittle and unsafe in real-world scenarios, so mission-critical use requires human-in-the-loop control and secure, sandboxed environments. Existing remote desktop protocols (VNC/RDP) are not optimized for dynamic handoff between AI and human controllers or for low-latency, low-bandwidth hybrid interaction across heterogeneous OS environments.
AI.method: Design and implementation of AgentBay, a sandbox service that offers secure, isolated environments (Windows, Linux, Android, browsers, code interpreters) exposed via a unified session. They introduce a hybrid control interface where AI agents connect programmatically (MCP, SDK) and humans can take over control at any time. A new Adaptive Streaming Protocol (ASP) underlies the system, dynamically switching and blending command-based and video-based streaming depending on network conditions and whether an AI or human is in control. They evaluate security properties, performance metrics (bandwidth, latency), and task completion on complex benchmarks, comparing against standard protocols like RDP and against agent-only baselines.
AI.result: AgentBay with combined Agent + Human control improves complex task success rates by more than 48% over non-hybrid baselines. The ASP protocol cuts bandwidth consumption by up to 50% versus standard RDP and reduces end-to-end latency by around 5%, particularly under poor network conditions. The system maintains secure isolation across multiple OS targets while enabling seamless controller handoff.
AI.conclusion: A purpose-built sandbox plus streaming stack for hybrid AI-human control can substantially improve reliability and efficiency of autonomous agent systems. AgentBay’s unified session and ASP protocol demonstrate that dynamic adaptation between command and video streaming, combined with instant human takeover, yields better task completion, lower bandwidth, and competitive latency, establishing a useful primitive for building robust human-supervised autonomous systems.

title: Executable Governance for AI: Translating Policies into Rules Using LLMs
comment: Accepted to AAAI-26 AI Governance Workshop (in-person presentation); 10 pages, 5 figures
summary: AI policy guidance is predominantly written as prose, which practitioners must first convert into executable rules before frameworks can evaluate or enforce them. This manual step is slow, error-prone, difficult to scale, and often delays the use of safeguards in real-world deployments. To address this gap, we present Policy-to-Tests (P2T), a framework that converts natural-language policy documents into normalized, machine-readable rules. The framework comprises a pipeline and a compact domain-specific language (DSL) that encodes hazards, scope, conditions, exceptions, and required evidence, yielding a canonical representation of extracted rules. To test the framework beyond a single policy, we apply it across general frameworks, sector guidance, and enterprise standards, extracting obligation-bearing clauses and converting them into executable rules. These AI-generated rules closely match strong human baselines on span-level and rule-level metrics, with robust inter-annotator agreement on the gold set. To evaluate downstream behavioral and safety impact, we add HIPAA-derived safeguards to a generative agent and compare it with an otherwise identical agent without guardrails. An LLM-based judge, aligned with gold-standard criteria, measures violation rates and robustness to obfuscated and compositional prompts. Detailed results are provided in the appendix. We release the codebase, DSL, prompts, and rule sets as open-source resources to enable reproducible evaluation.

AI.tldr: They propose P2T, a system that turns natural-language AI policy documents into machine-readable, executable rules, validate it across multiple policy sources, and show that adding such rules can measurably improve LLM safety behavior.
AI.motivation: Current AI policy guidance is written in prose, requiring humans to manually translate it into concrete, testable rules. This translation is slow, error-prone, hard to scale, and delays real-world deployment of safeguards. There is a need for an automated, systematic way to convert natural-language policies into machine-usable representations so that compliance and safety checks can be applied reliably and at scale.
AI.method: They design Policy-to-Tests (P2T), which includes (1) a pipeline that processes natural-language policy documents and extracts obligation-bearing clauses and (2) a compact domain-specific language (DSL) that encodes each rule as hazards, scope, conditions, exceptions, and required evidence. The output is a normalized, canonical rule representation. They apply P2T to a variety of policy sources—general AI frameworks, sector-specific guidance (e.g., healthcare), and enterprise standards—and compare the AI-generated rules against strong human baselines using span-level and rule-level metrics, with inter-annotator agreement to validate the gold labels. For downstream evaluation, they instantiate HIPAA-like safeguards as rules, integrate them into a generative agent as guardrails, and compare its behavior with a nearly identical unguided agent. An LLM-based judge, calibrated to gold-standard criteria, evaluates violation rates and robustness under obfuscated and compositional prompts.
AI.result: P2T successfully converts diverse natural-language policy documents into executable rules expressed in the DSL, capturing hazards, scope, conditions, exceptions, and required evidence. The automatically generated rules closely match human-authored rules on span- and rule-level matching metrics, and the gold-standard annotations show robust inter-annotator agreement, suggesting that the task is well-defined and that P2T’s outputs are high quality. In downstream tests, a generative agent equipped with HIPAA-derived rules via P2T exhibits lower policy violation rates and maintains robustness even when facing obfuscated or compositional prompts, as judged by an LLM evaluator aligned with human gold criteria. Detailed quantitative metrics are relegated to the appendix, but the abstract reports clear improvements over the no-guardrail baseline.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates that policy prose can be automatically converted into normalized, executable rules using the P2T framework and its domain-specific language, producing rule sets that closely approximate human-crafted ones. This enables scalable and reproducible application of AI safety and compliance safeguards. When integrated into generative agents, these policy-derived rules reduce violations and improve robustness to adversarial prompting. By releasing their code, DSL, prompts, and rule sets as open-source assets, the authors aim to facilitate broader, standardized evaluation and deployment of AI policy compliance tools.

title: SignRoundV2: Closing the Performance Gap in Extremely Low-Bit Post-Training Quantization for LLMs
summary: Extreme low-bit quantization is critical for efficiently deploying Large Language Models (LLMs), yet it often leads to severe performance degradation at 2-bits and even 4-bits (e.g., MXFP4). We present SignRoundV2, a post-training quantization framework that is highly effective even without mixed-precision. SignRoundV2 introduces (1) a fast sensitivity metric that combines gradient information with quantization-induced deviations to guide layer-wise bit allocation, and (2) a lightweight pre-tuning search for quantization scales to improve extremely low-bit quantization. These components allow SignRoundV2 to close the gap with full-precision models. Extensive experiments indicate that our method sustains competitive accuracy for LLMs, achieving production-grade performance with about 1 percent variance at 4-5 bits and strong results even at 2 bits. The implementation is available at https://github.com/intel/auto-round.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes SignRoundV2, a post‑training quantization framework that maintains near–full-precision performance for large language models at very low bit-widths (2–5 bits).
AI.motivation: Deploying LLMs efficiently requires aggressive quantization to reduce memory and compute, but existing 2–4 bit schemes cause significant accuracy loss, especially in production settings. There is a need for a method that can push bit-widths very low while preserving model quality, without relying heavily on mixed precision or expensive retraining.
AI.method: SignRoundV2 is a post‑training quantization method with two main components: (1) a fast layer-wise sensitivity metric that combines gradient information and quantization-induced deviations to decide how many bits to allocate to each layer; (2) a lightweight pre-tuning search over quantization scales to find settings that minimize the error at extremely low bit-widths. The framework aims to work end-to-end without mixed precision and with modest computational overhead.
AI.result: Experiments on LLMs show that SignRoundV2 maintains accuracy close to full-precision models: around 1% performance variance at 4–5 bits and strong accuracy even at 2 bits, outperforming existing low-bit post‑training quantization baselines.
AI.conclusion: SignRoundV2 enables practical, production-grade deployment of LLMs at very low bit-widths by combining sensitivity-aware bit allocation and scale pre-tuning, substantially narrowing the performance gap between low-bit and full-precision models while remaining a post‑training approach.

title: GovBench: Benchmarking LLM Agents for Real-World Data Governance Workflows
comment: Equal contribution: Zhou Liu and Zhaoyang Han. Corresponding authors: Yuanfeng Song and Wentao Zhang
summary: Data governance ensures data quality, security, and compliance through policies and standards, a critical foundation for scaling modern AI development. Recently, large language models (LLMs) have emerged as a promising solution for automating data governance by translating user intent into executable transformation code. However, existing benchmarks for automated data science often emphasize snippet-level coding or high-level analytics, failing to capture the unique challenge of data governance: ensuring the correctness and quality of the data itself. To bridge this gap, we introduce GovBench, a benchmark featuring 150 diverse tasks grounded in real-world scenarios, built on data from actual cases. GovBench employs a novel "reversed-objective" methodology to synthesize realistic noise and utilizes rigorous metrics to assess end-to-end pipeline reliability. Our analysis on GovBench reveals that current models struggle with complex, multi-step workflows and lack robust error-correction mechanisms. Consequently, we propose DataGovAgent, a framework utilizing a Planner-Executor-Evaluator architecture that integrates constraint-based planning, retrieval-augmented generation, and sandboxed feedback-driven debugging. Experimental results show that DataGovAgent significantly boosts the Average Task Score (ATS) on complex tasks from 39.7 to 54.9 and reduces debugging iterations by over 77.9 percent compared to general-purpose baselines.

AI.tldr: They introduce GovBench, a realistic benchmark for automated data governance with LLMs, and propose DataGovAgent, an agentic system that significantly improves performance on this benchmark.
AI.motivation: Existing AI and LLM benchmarks for automated data science focus on code snippets or high-level analytics, not on the core difficulty of data governance: reliably improving data quality and correctness in realistic, noisy, multi-step pipelines. There’s no standard way to test whether LLM-based systems can robustly handle real-world governance tasks such as cleaning, validating, and transforming messy data under constraints. This gap hinders the development and fair comparison of systems aimed at automating data governance.
AI.method: 1) Construct GovBench, a benchmark of 150 tasks derived from real-world data governance cases, where realistic noise is injected via a new “reversed-objective” process: start from clean data and goals, then systematically corrupt or perturb data to create realistic governance problems. 2) Define rigorous metrics for end-to-end pipeline reliability, not just code correctness. 3) Empirically evaluate existing LLM and agent baselines on GovBench to characterize their limitations. 4) Propose DataGovAgent, a Planner-Executor-Evaluator framework that combines constraint-based planning to break down tasks, retrieval-augmented generation for more informed decisions, and sandboxed, feedback-driven debugging loops to iteratively improve transformation pipelines.
AI.result: On GovBench, current LLM-based systems are shown to perform poorly on complex, multi-step data governance tasks and lack effective self-correction. DataGovAgent, in contrast, substantially improves performance on these harder tasks, increasing the Average Task Score (ATS) from 39.7 to 54.9 and cutting the number of debugging iterations by more than 77.9% relative to general-purpose baselines.
AI.conclusion: GovBench exposes that existing LLM-based tools are not yet reliable for realistic data governance workflows. The proposed DataGovAgent architecture, evaluated on GovBench, demonstrates that structured planning, retrieval, and sandboxed debugging can materially enhance robustness and efficiency. GovBench plus DataGovAgent together provide both a standardized evaluation setting and a promising blueprint for more capable automated data governance systems.

title: Model Whisper: Steering Vectors Unlock Large Language Models' Potential in Test-time
summary: It is a critical challenge to efficiently unlock the powerful reasoning potential of Large Language Models (LLMs) for specific tasks or new distributions. Existing test-time adaptation methods often require tuning model parameters, which is not only computationally expensive but also risks degrading the model's pre-existing abilities.To address this, we introduce a lightweight component, Test-Time Steering Vectors (TTSV), which is prepended to the input while keeping the LLM's parameters entirely frozen. By optimizing the TTSV on test data to minimize the model's output entropy, we steer the model towards an internal state of higher confidence, activating its inherent abilities most relevant to the current task. TTSV is both lightweight and highly efficient to optimize, making it a true plug-and-play enhancement. Extensive experiments validate our approach's effectiveness on both base models and reasoning-enhanced models. For instance, on the MATH500 task, TTSV achieves a 45.88% relative performance gain on the Qwen2.5-Math-7B model and a 16.22% relative gain on the Qwen3-4B model. Furthermore, our approach exhibits robust generalization, with its steering vectors proving highly transferable across diverse tasks.

AI.tldr: They propose a plug-and-play way to adapt large language models at test time using small trainable vectors added to the input, improving reasoning without changing model weights.
AI.motivation: Test-time adaptation for LLMs is useful for new tasks or distributions but current methods need updating model parameters, which is slow, costly, and may harm existing capabilities. The authors want an efficient, safe way to unlock a model’s reasoning power for specific tasks without touching its weights.
AI.method: They introduce Test-Time Steering Vectors (TTSV), a small, learnable vector prepended to the input tokens while all LLM parameters remain frozen. At test time, they optimize this vector on the test data by minimizing the model’s output entropy, thereby nudging the internal activations toward more confident and relevant reasoning states. The optimization is lightweight and fast, so TTSV can be attached to different models and tasks as a plug-and-play component.
AI.result: Across various benchmarks and both base and reasoning-optimized models, TTSV yields consistent performance improvements. On MATH500, it raises Qwen2.5-Math-7B’s accuracy by 45.88% relatively and Qwen3-4B’s by 16.22% relatively, and the learned steering vectors transfer well across different tasks, indicating strong generalization.
AI.conclusion: Optimizing a small, prepended steering vector at test time—without any weight updates—can effectively steer LLMs into more confident and task-relevant reasoning modes. This yields substantial accuracy gains, is computationally efficient, and generalizes across tasks, offering a practical plug-and-play alternative to conventional test-time adaptation methods.

title: Solving LLM Repetition Problem in Production: A Comprehensive Study of Multiple Solutions
summary:
The repetition problem, where Large Language Models (LLMs) continuously generate repetitive content without proper termination, poses a critical challenge in production deployments, causing severe performance degradation and system stalling. This paper presents a comprehensive investigation and multiple practical solutions for the repetition problem encountered in real-world batch code interpretation tasks.
  We identify three distinct repetition patterns: (1) business rule generation repetition, (2) method call relationship analysis repetition, and (3) PlantUML diagram syntax generation repetition. Through rigorous theoretical analysis based on Markov models, we establish that the root cause lies in greedy decoding's inability to escape repetitive loops, exacerbated by self-reinforcement effects.
  Our comprehensive experimental evaluation demonstrates three viable solutions: (1) Beam Search decoding with early_stopping=True serves as a universal post-hoc mechanism that effectively resolves all three repetition patterns; (2) presence_penalty hyperparameter provides an effective solution specifically for BadCase 1; and (3) Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) fine-tuning offers a universal model-level solution for all three BadCases.
  The primary value of this work lies in combining first-hand production experience with extensive experimental validation. Our main contributions include systematic theoretical analysis of repetition mechanisms, comprehensive evaluation of multiple solutions with task-specific applicability mapping, identification of early_stopping as the critical parameter for Beam Search effectiveness, and practical production-ready solutions validated in real deployment environments.

AI.tldr: The paper studies why large language models sometimes get stuck generating repetitive outputs in real-world batch code interpretation tasks and evaluates several practical fixes.
AI.motivation: In production systems using LLMs for code-related tasks, models can enter infinite or very long repetitive loops, harming performance and reliability. Existing discussions of repetition are often anecdotal or lack systematic analysis across real deployment scenarios. The authors want to understand the mechanisms behind these failures and identify robust, easy-to-deploy mitigation strategies.
AI.method: The authors first categorize three concrete repetition patterns observed in practice: repetition in business rule generation, in method call relationship analysis, and in PlantUML syntax generation. They then analyze the repetition behavior theoretically using Markov models, focusing on how greedy decoding can enter self-reinforcing loops. Experimentally, they test different decoding strategies (greedy vs beam search with early stopping), hyperparameter tweaks (presence_penalty), and model-level training approaches (DPO fine-tuning), and measure their impact on the three repetition patterns in batch code interpretation tasks.
AI.result: They find that greedy decoding is especially vulnerable to entering repetitive loops due to self-reinforcement where repeated tokens keep being favored. Beam search with early_stopping=True consistently eliminates the three observed repetition patterns as a decoding-time, model-agnostic fix. The presence_penalty hyperparameter effectively mitigates repetition for the first pattern (business rule generation) but does not generalize across all patterns. DPO fine-tuning yields a model-level solution that prevents all three repetition types without relying solely on decoding tweaks.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that repetition in LLM outputs for code interpretation is a systematic decoding issue rather than just noisy behavior, and can be explained using a Markov-model-based analysis of greedy decoding loops. Beam search with early stopping emerges as a strong, broadly applicable operational fix, while presence_penalty is task-specific and DPO fine-tuning offers a more fundamental, model-level remedy. The work provides theoretically grounded, experimentally validated, and production-tested guidance on how to detect and mitigate repetition problems in real-world LLM deployments.

title: EtCon: Edit-then-Consolidate for Reliable Knowledge Editing
summary: Knowledge editing aims to update specific facts in large language models (LLMs) without full retraining. Prior efforts sought to tune the knowledge layers of LLMs, proving effective for making selective edits. However, a significant gap exists between their performance in controlled, teacher-forcing evaluations and their real-world effectiveness in lifelong learning scenarios, which greatly limits their practical applicability. This work's empirical analysis reveals two recurring issues associated with this gap: (1) Most traditional methods lead the edited model to overfit to the new fact, thereby degrading pre-trained capabilities; (2) There is a critical absence of a knowledge consolidation stage, leaving new facts insufficiently integrated into LLMs' inference-time behavior under autoregressive generation, thereby leading to a mismatch between parametric knowledge and actual generation behavior. To this end, we propose Edit-then-Consolidate, a novel knowledge editing paradigm that aims to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge editing methods and their real-world applicability. Specifically, (1) our framework mitigates overfitting via Targeted Proximal Supervised Fine-Tuning (TPSFT) that localizes the edit via a trust-region objective to limit policy drift; (2) Then, a consolidation stage using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) aligns the edited knowledge with CoT-based inference policy by optimizing trajectory-level behavior under comprehensive reward signals. Extensive experiments demonstrate our framework consistently improves editing reliability and generalization under real-world evaluations, while better preserving locality and pre-trained capabilities.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Edit-then-Consolidate, a two-stage framework for more reliable, localized, and practically effective knowledge editing in LLMs, combining constrained supervised fine-tuning with a reinforcement-style consolidation step to align edited knowledge with real-world autoregressive behavior.
AI.motivation: Existing knowledge editing methods for LLMs work well in controlled, teacher-forcing settings but fail to perform reliably in realistic, lifelong learning scenarios. They often cause overfitting to new facts that harms general capabilities, and they lack a consolidation mechanism to ensure that newly edited parametric knowledge actually manifests in autoregressive generation and chain-of-thought reasoning. This gap between offline metrics and real-world behavior limits the practicality of current editing approaches, motivating a new paradigm that both localizes edits and consolidates them into the model’s inference policy.
AI.method: The authors propose a two-stage paradigm called Edit-then-Consolidate. First, they perform Targeted Proximal Supervised Fine-Tuning (TPSFT), which applies supervised fine-tuning to inject new facts while constraining updates through a trust-region style objective to limit policy drift and localize edits. Second, they run a consolidation stage using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), a policy-optimization procedure at the trajectory level that leverages comprehensive reward signals and chain-of-thought (CoT) style inference to align the model’s generative behavior and reasoning policy with the newly edited knowledge. This combination addresses both the overfitting and the lack of consolidation observed in prior work.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, the Edit-then-Consolidate framework shows higher editing reliability and improved generalization on real-world-style evaluations compared to prior methods. It better preserves locality, meaning it avoids unintended changes to unrelated knowledge, and maintains more of the model’s pre-trained capabilities while still successfully integrating new facts into its generative behavior. Empirical analyses highlight reduced overfitting and improved alignment between parametric edits and actual autoregressive outputs.
AI.conclusion: By treating knowledge editing as a two-stage process—localized injection of new facts followed by explicit consolidation into the model’s inference-time policy—Edit-then-Consolidate narrows the gap between theoretical editing performance and practical, lifelong learning behavior in LLMs. The proposed TPSFT and GRPO components together enable more precise, robust, and behaviorally aligned knowledge updates, offering a more viable path toward continual model updating without full retraining.

title: TaskEval: Synthesised Evaluation for Foundation-Model Tasks
summary: Hallucinations are a key concern when creating applications that rely on Foundation models (FMs). Understanding where and how these subtle failures occur in an application relies on evaluation methods known as \textit{evals}. Prior work focuses on defining new eval methods or benchmark datasets for specific tasks. However, neither helps a software team with a task-specific FM application when there is no metric or dataset. The demand for both automated approaches and deep integration of human insight makes this a challenging problem. We address this gap by proposing an approach to synthesise a FM task-specific evaluator program that provides automation and a custom UI for capturing feedback. The core novelty of our approach lies in: (1) a task-agnostic meta-model that captures properties of any FM task, (2) an interaction protocol for efficient use of human feedback, and (3) an eval synthesiser that selects or generates an appropriate set of evals. We implement our approach in \toolname and demonstrate the concept on two diverse FM tasks: chart data extraction and document question answering. A preliminary evaluation on the quality of our selected evals shows 93\% and 90\% accuracy respectively. Our research tackles a growing problem facing engineering teams, how to evaluate and review outputs from FM tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a system that automatically builds task-specific evaluation programs and UIs to detect hallucinations and assess outputs of Foundation Model applications, even when no existing metrics or datasets are available.
AI.motivation: Foundation models often hallucinate, and current evaluation methods are either new metrics or fixed benchmark datasets tailored to specific tasks. These are not directly useful to engineering teams building bespoke FM-powered applications that lack ready-made metrics or datasets. Teams need ways to both automate evaluation and tightly integrate human feedback, but doing so in a scalable, task-specific manner is difficult.
AI.method: The authors propose a framework that synthesizes task-specific evaluator programs for FM applications. The method has three key components: (1) a task-agnostic meta-model that can represent the properties and structure of any FM task; (2) a human–AI interaction protocol to efficiently collect and use human feedback during evaluation; and (3) an eval synthesizer that, based on the task description and meta-model, selects or generates a suitable set of evaluation procedures and a custom UI for feedback capture. This is instantiated in a system called \toolname.
AI.result: The system is implemented as \toolname and tested on two distinct tasks: chart data extraction and document question answering. The automatically selected or generated evals for these tasks achieved preliminary accuracy scores of 93% and 90%, indicating that the synthesized evaluators reliably judge the correctness or quality of FM outputs.
AI.conclusion: Automatically synthesizing evaluators and feedback UIs from a task-agnostic meta-model is a promising way to evaluate FM-based applications where no off-the-shelf metrics or datasets exist. The approach can support engineering teams in systematically reviewing FM outputs and identifying hallucinations across diverse tasks.

title: Challenging the Abilities of Large Language Models in Italian: a Community Initiative
summary: The rapid progress of Large Language Models (LLMs) has transformed natural language processing and broadened its impact across research and society. Yet, systematic evaluation of these models, especially for languages beyond English, remains limited. "Challenging the Abilities of LAnguage Models in ITAlian" (CALAMITA) is a large-scale collaborative benchmarking initiative for Italian, coordinated under the Italian Association for Computational Linguistics. Unlike existing efforts that focus on leaderboards, CALAMITA foregrounds methodology: it federates more than 80 contributors from academia, industry, and the public sector to design, document, and evaluate a diverse collection of tasks, covering linguistic competence, commonsense reasoning, factual consistency, fairness, summarization, translation, and code generation. Through this process, we not only assembled a benchmark of over 20 tasks and almost 100 subtasks, but also established a centralized evaluation pipeline that supports heterogeneous datasets and metrics. We report results for four open-weight LLMs, highlighting systematic strengths and weaknesses across abilities, as well as challenges in task-specific evaluation. Beyond quantitative results, CALAMITA exposes methodological lessons: the necessity of fine-grained, task-representative metrics, the importance of harmonized pipelines, and the benefits and limitations of broad community engagement. CALAMITA is conceived as a rolling benchmark, enabling continuous integration of new tasks and models. This makes it both a resource -- the most comprehensive and diverse benchmark for Italian to date -- and a framework for sustainable, community-driven evaluation. We argue that this combination offers a blueprint for other languages and communities seeking inclusive and rigorous LLM evaluation practices.

AI.tldr: CALAMITA is a large, collaborative benchmark and evaluation pipeline for testing many abilities of LLMs in Italian, offering tasks, metrics, and infrastructure plus methodological lessons for future evaluations.
AI.motivation: LLMs are advancing quickly, but systematic, rigorous evaluation beyond English—especially for Italian—is underdeveloped. Existing leaderboards often prioritize rankings over sound methodology, lack coverage of many important abilities, and do not provide standardized, reusable pipelines for heterogeneous tasks and metrics. The authors want to fill this gap for Italian and to propose an evaluation blueprint that other language communities can adopt.
AI.method: They organized a large collaborative effort under the Italian Association for Computational Linguistics, involving more than 80 contributors from academia, industry, and the public sector. Together they designed and documented a broad suite of over 20 tasks and ~100 subtasks that probe different capabilities: linguistic competence, commonsense reasoning, factual consistency, fairness, summarization, translation, and code generation. They built a centralized evaluation pipeline capable of handling these heterogeneous datasets and metrics in a harmonized way. They then evaluated four open-weight LLMs on the benchmark and analyzed performance patterns across tasks and subtasks.
AI.result: The project delivered: (1) a comprehensive Italian benchmark spanning 20+ tasks and nearly 100 subtasks, covering a wide set of abilities; (2) a unified, centralized evaluation pipeline that supports diverse datasets and metrics; and (3) empirical results on four open-weight LLMs, revealing systematic strengths and weaknesses, as well as concrete difficulties and pitfalls in task-specific evaluation. The work also surfaced important methodological insights regarding metric design, pipeline harmonization, and community-based development processes.
AI.conclusion: CALAMITA is both a resource and a methodological framework: it is currently the most comprehensive, diverse benchmark for evaluating LLMs in Italian, and its rolling, extensible design supports the ongoing integration of new tasks and models. The authors conclude that fine-grained, task-aligned metrics and harmonized evaluation infrastructures are crucial, and that broad community engagement brings both benefits and challenges. They propose CALAMITA as a blueprint that other language communities can adapt to build inclusive, rigorous, and sustainable LLM evaluation practices beyond English.

title: MARL Warehouse Robots
summary: We present a comparative study of multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) algorithms for cooperative warehouse robotics. We evaluate QMIX and IPPO on the Robotic Warehouse (RWARE) environment and a custom Unity 3D simulation. Our experiments reveal that QMIX's value decomposition significantly outperforms independent learning approaches (achieving 3.25 mean return vs. 0.38 for advanced IPPO), but requires extensive hyperparameter tuning -- particularly extended epsilon annealing (5M+ steps) for sparse reward discovery. We demonstrate successful deployment in Unity ML-Agents, achieving consistent package delivery after 1M training steps. While MARL shows promise for small-scale deployments (2-4 robots), significant scaling challenges remain. Code and analyses: https://pallman14.github.io/MARL-QMIX-Warehouse-Robots/

AI.tldr: Comparative study of MARL algorithms (QMIX vs IPPO) for cooperative warehouse robots, showing QMIX with value decomposition performs much better but needs heavy tuning and faces scaling issues.
AI.motivation: To understand which MARL methods are more effective for coordinating cooperative warehouse robots, and to explore practical training/deployment issues such as sparse rewards, hyperparameter sensitivity, and scalability.
AI.method: Experimentally compare QMIX and independent PPO (IPPO) on the RWARE benchmark and a custom Unity 3D warehouse simulation; analyze learning performance, hyperparameter sensitivity (e.g., epsilon annealing), and deployment behavior of trained policies.
AI.result: QMIX with value decomposition substantially outperforms IPPO (mean return 3.25 vs. 0.38) but only with careful hyperparameter tuning, especially very long epsilon annealing schedules (over 5M steps) to handle sparse rewards; successful Unity ML-Agents deployment achieves reliable package delivery after around 1M training steps; performance degrades or becomes hard to scale beyond 2–4 robots.
AI.conclusion: Value-decomposition MARL (QMIX) is more effective than independent policy-gradient methods (IPPO) for small cooperative warehouse tasks, but its practical success hinges on intensive tuning and it does not yet scale well to larger multi-robot systems.

title: AdiBhashaa: A Community-Curated Benchmark for Machine Translation into Indian Tribal Languages
summary: Large language models and multilingual machine translation (MT) systems increasingly drive access to information, yet many languages of the tribal communities remain effectively invisible in these technologies. This invisibility exacerbates existing structural inequities in education, governance, and digital participation. We present AdiBhashaa, a community-driven initiative that constructs the first open parallel corpora and baseline MT systems for four major Indian tribal languages-Bhili, Mundari, Gondi, and Santali. This work combines participatory data creation with native speakers, human-in-the-loop validation, and systematic evaluation of both encoder-decoder MT models and large language models. In addition to reporting technical findings, we articulate how AdiBhashaa illustrates a possible model for more equitable AI research: it centers local expertise, builds capacity among early-career researchers from marginalized communities, and foregrounds human validation in the development of language technologies.

AI.tldr: AdiBhashaa builds the first open corpora and baseline machine translation systems for four major Indian tribal languages using a community-driven, human‑validated approach, and proposes this as a model for more equitable AI research.
AI.motivation: Many tribal community languages are effectively invisible in current large language models and multilingual MT systems, reinforcing structural inequities in education, governance, and digital participation. The authors aim to reduce this digital marginalization by creating resources and tools for these under-served languages and by rethinking how AI research involving marginalized communities is conducted.
AI.method: The project, AdiBhashaa, develops open parallel corpora and baseline MT systems for four Indian tribal languages (Bhili, Mundari, Gondi, Santali). It uses participatory data creation with native speakers, human-in-the-loop validation of the data and models, and systematic evaluation of both traditional encoder–decoder MT models and large language models. The process is explicitly community-driven and capacity-building for local researchers.
AI.result: AdiBhashaa produces the first open parallel corpora and baseline machine translation models for the four targeted tribal languages and evaluates their performance across different model architectures, including encoder–decoder MT systems and large language models. It also documents empirical behavior of these models on low-resource, marginalized languages under a carefully validated data regime.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates that community-driven, human-validated approaches can bootstrap high-impact language technologies for severely under-served tribal languages. AdiBhashaa is proposed as a template for more equitable AI research that centers local expertise, trains early-career researchers from marginalized communities, and keeps human validation central to the development and deployment of language technologies.

title: Mathematical Framing for Different Agent Strategies
summary: We introduce a unified mathematical and probabilistic framework for understanding and comparing diverse AI agent strategies. We bridge the gap between high-level agent design concepts, such as ReAct, multi-agent systems, and control flows, and a rigorous mathematical formulation. Our approach frames agentic processes as a chain of probabilities, enabling a detailed analysis of how different strategies manipulate these probabilities to achieve desired outcomes. Our framework provides a common language for discussing the trade-offs inherent in various agent architectures. One of our many key contributions is the introduction of the "Degrees of Freedom" concept, which intuitively differentiates the optimizable levers available for each approach, thereby guiding the selection of appropriate strategies for specific tasks. This work aims to enhance the clarity and precision in designing and evaluating AI agents, offering insights into maximizing the probability of successful actions within complex agentic systems.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a unified probabilistic framework to describe, compare, and analyze different AI agent strategies and architectures.
AI.motivation: Current AI agent designs (e.g., ReAct, multi-agent systems, complex control flows) are described mostly at a heuristic or conceptual level, making it hard to rigorously compare them, understand their trade-offs, or systematically choose the right architecture for a given task.
AI.method: The authors model agentic processes as chains of probabilistic events, defining how different strategies correspond to different ways of manipulating these probability chains. They introduce a formal notion of "Degrees of Freedom" to represent the optimizable levers within each agent architecture and use this to characterize and compare approaches like ReAct, multi-agent workflows, and other control structures within a single mathematical language.
AI.result: They obtain a unified, mathematically grounded description of diverse agent strategies, show how these strategies can be viewed as different configurations of probabilistic chains and degrees of freedom, and provide a structured way to analyze and compare their trade-offs in terms of controllable and optimizable components.
AI.conclusion: The framework clarifies how various AI agent architectures operate at a probabilistic level, offers a common language for reasoning about their design choices, and helps practitioners select and tune agent strategies to maximize the probability of successful actions in complex tasks.

title: DaLA: Danish Linguistic Acceptability Evaluation Guided by Real World Errors
summary: We present an enhanced benchmark for evaluating linguistic acceptability in Danish. We first analyze the most common errors found in written Danish. Based on this analysis, we introduce a set of fourteen corruption functions that generate incorrect sentences by systematically introducing errors into existing correct Danish sentences. To ensure the accuracy of these corruptions, we assess their validity using both manual and automatic methods. The results are then used as a benchmark for evaluating Large Language Models on a linguistic acceptability judgement task. Our findings demonstrate that this extension is both broader and more comprehensive than the current state of the art. By incorporating a greater variety of corruption types, our benchmark provides a more rigorous assessment of linguistic acceptability, increasing task difficulty, as evidenced by the lower performance of LLMs on our benchmark compared to existing ones. Our results also suggest that our benchmark has a higher discriminatory power which allows to better distinguish well-performing models from low-performing ones.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an enhanced Danish linguistic acceptability benchmark created by systematically corrupting correct sentences using 14 error functions, and shows it is harder and more discriminative for evaluating LLMs than existing benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks for linguistic acceptability in Danish are limited in coverage and types of errors, making it hard to rigorously evaluate and distinguish the capabilities of Large Language Models on this task. The authors want a broader, more realistic, and more discriminative benchmark.
AI.method: They first analyze common errors in written Danish. From this analysis, they design fourteen specific corruption functions that can introduce realistic grammatical and linguistic errors into otherwise correct Danish sentences. They apply these corruption functions to generate incorrect sentences. They then validate the accuracy and naturalness of these corruptions using both manual (human) and automatic checks. The resulting dataset (correct vs. corrupted sentences) is used as a benchmark to test LLM performance on linguistic acceptability judgments.
AI.result: The new benchmark contains a wider range of corruption types and is more comprehensive than current Danish acceptability benchmarks. Large Language Models perform worse on this new benchmark than on existing ones, showing that it is more challenging. Performance differences between models are more pronounced, indicating higher discriminatory power in distinguishing strong from weak models.
AI.conclusion: The enhanced benchmark, built from systematically generated and validated corruptions, offers a more rigorous, challenging, and discriminative way to evaluate LLMs on Danish linguistic acceptability. It improves over prior benchmarks in both breadth of error types and its ability to differentiate model performance.

title: AI-Assisted Game Management Decisions: A Fuzzy Logic Approach to Real-Time Substituitions
summary: In elite soccer, substitution decisions entail significant financial and sporting consequences yet remain heavily reliant on intuition or predictive models that merely mimic historical biases. This paper introduces a Fuzzy Logic based Decision Support System (DSS) designed for real time, prescriptive game management. Unlike traditional Machine Learning approaches that encounter a predictive ceiling by attempting to replicate human behavior, our system audits performance through an objective, rule based inference engine. We propose a methodological advancement by reformulating the PlayeRank metric into a Cumulative Mean with Role Aware Normalization, eliminating the play time exposure bias inherent in cumulative sum models to enable accurate intra match comparison. The system integrates this refined metric with physiological proxies (fatigue) and contextual variables (disciplinary risk modulated by tactical role) to calculate a dynamic Substitution Priority (P final). Validation via a case study of the 2018 FIFA World Cup match between Brazil and Belgium demonstrates the system's ecological validity: it not only aligned with expert consensus on executed substitutions (for example Gabriel Jesus) but, crucially, identified high risk scenarios ignored by human decision makers. Specifically, the model flagged the "FAGNER Paradox" - a maximum priority defensive risk - minutes before a critical yellow card, and detected the "Lukaku Paradox", where an isolated assist masked a severe drop in participation. These results confirm that Fuzzy Logic offers a transparent, explainable, and superior alternative to black box models for optimizing real time tactical decisions.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a fuzzy‑logic decision support system to improve in‑game substitution decisions in elite soccer, overcoming biases in human judgment and traditional machine‑learning approaches.
AI.motivation: Substitution choices in elite soccer have large financial and sporting consequences but are often made intuitively or with models that just reproduce historical coaching biases. There is a need for an objective, real‑time, explainable tool that helps optimize substitutions based on player performance, fatigue and contextual risk, rather than merely predicting what coaches usually do.
AI.method: The authors build a Fuzzy Logic–based Decision Support System for real‑time substitution management. They reformulate the PlayeRank performance metric as a Cumulative Mean with Role‑Aware Normalization to remove playing‑time exposure bias and enable fair within‑match comparisons. This performance measure is combined with proxies of physiological status (fatigue) and contextual variables such as disciplinary risk, adjusted for tactical role, within a rule‑based fuzzy inference engine to compute a dynamic Substitution Priority score (P_final) for each player.
AI.result: In a case study of the Brazil vs Belgium match at the 2018 FIFA World Cup, the system’s recommendations matched expert opinion regarding some actual substitutions (e.g., Gabriel Jesus) while also revealing critical risks that human staff overlooked. The model highlighted a high‑priority defensive risk for player Fagner shortly before he received a yellow card, and it showed that Lukaku’s apparent effectiveness, due to an assist, concealed a significant decline in overall involvement, which the system classified as a paradoxical situation.
AI.conclusion: Fuzzy Logic, combined with a role‑normalized performance metric and contextual risk indicators, can provide transparent and explainable substitution recommendations that outperform both traditional machine‑learning models, which tend to replicate human biases, and purely intuitive coaching decisions. This approach offers a promising framework for more rational, real‑time tactical decision‑making in elite soccer.

authors: L. D. M. S. Sai Teja
title: DAMASHA: Detecting AI in Mixed Adversarial Texts via Segmentation with Human-interpretable Attribution
summary: In the age of advanced large language models (LLMs), the boundaries between human and AI-generated text are becoming increasingly blurred. We address the challenge of segmenting mixed-authorship text, that is identifying transition points in text where authorship shifts from human to AI or vice-versa, a problem with critical implications for authenticity, trust, and human oversight. We introduce a novel framework, called Info-Mask for mixed authorship detection that integrates stylometric cues, perplexity-driven signals, and structured boundary modeling to accurately segment collaborative human-AI content. To evaluate the robustness of our system against adversarial perturbations, we construct and release an adversarial benchmark dataset Mixed-text Adversarial setting for Segmentation (MAS), designed to probe the limits of existing detectors. Beyond segmentation accuracy, we introduce Human-Interpretable Attribution (HIA overlays that highlight how stylometric features inform boundary predictions, and we conduct a small-scale human study assessing their usefulness. Across multiple architectures, Info-Mask significantly improves span-level robustness under adversarial conditions, establishing new baselines while revealing remaining challenges. Our findings highlight both the promise and limitations of adversarially robust, interpretable mixed-authorship detection, with implications for trust and oversight in human-AI co-authorship.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes Info-Mask, a framework for segmenting mixed human-AI authored text, improving robustness and interpretability in detecting authorship boundaries under adversarial conditions.
AI.motivation: As LLMs advance, distinguishing between human and AI-generated text becomes harder, especially when they are interleaved within the same document. This raises concerns for authenticity, trust, and oversight in settings like editing, co-writing, or moderation. Existing detectors typically classify whole documents and are brittle to adversarial perturbations, lacking fine-grained, interpretable boundary detection between human and AI segments.
AI.method: The authors design Info-Mask, a segmentation framework that combines three main components: (1) stylometric analysis capturing writing style features; (2) perplexity-based signals that leverage language model likelihood differences between human and AI writing; and (3) a structured boundary modeling module that predicts where authorship shifts occur across a sequence. They additionally create MAS (Mixed-text Adversarial setting), a benchmark where mixed human–AI texts are perturbed adversarially to test robustness, and propose Human-Interpretable Attribution (HIA) overlays that visualize how stylometric cues contribute to boundary decisions. A small human study evaluates the interpretability and usefulness of these overlays.
AI.result: Across various model architectures, Info-Mask achieves higher span-level segmentation accuracy and better robustness on the MAS adversarial benchmark than existing mixed-authorship detectors. It establishes stronger baselines for detecting authorship boundaries in the presence of adversarial modifications. The HIA overlays are found in a user study to aid human understanding of why boundaries are placed where they are, though some usability challenges remain.
AI.conclusion: Info-Mask advances the state of the art in robust, fine-grained detection of mixed human-AI authorship by integrating stylometry, perplexity cues, and structured segmentation, while providing interpretable attributions. However, adversarial attacks still expose weaknesses, indicating that mixed-authorship detection remains an open challenge. The work underscores the importance of robust and interpretable tools for monitoring and governing human-AI co-authored text.

title: Persona-based Multi-Agent Collaboration for Brainstorming
summary: We demonstrate the importance of persona-based multi-agents brainstorming for both diverse topics and subject matter ideation. Prior work has shown that generalized multi-agent collaboration often provides better reasoning than a single agent alone. In this paper, we propose and develop a framework for persona-based agent selection, showing how persona domain curation can improve brainstorming outcomes. Using multiple experimental setups, we evaluate brainstorming outputs across different persona pairings (e.g., Doctor vs VR Engineer) and A2A (agent-to-agent) dynamics (separate, together, separate-then-together). Our results show that (1) persona choice shapes idea domains, (2) collaboration mode shifts diversity of idea generation, and (3) multi-agent persona-driven brainstorming produces idea depth and cross-domain coverage.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a persona-based multi-agent brainstorming framework and shows that choosing different personas and collaboration modes significantly affects the diversity, depth, and domain coverage of generated ideas.
AI.motivation: While prior research indicates that generic multi-agent collaboration can improve reasoning compared to single agents, less is known about how explicitly designed personas and their pairings influence brainstorming quality, diversity, and domain coverage. The authors aim to understand whether and how persona selection and interaction patterns can systematically steer ideation for both broad topics and specialized subject matter.
AI.method: The authors design a framework for persona-based agent selection and domain curation, defining different expert and non-expert personas (e.g., Doctor, VR Engineer) and specifying how they are combined. They experiment with various persona pairings and collaboration dynamics—agents working separately, together, and in separate-then-together (sequential) modes. They then evaluate the resulting brainstorming outputs in terms of domain coverage, diversity, and depth of ideas across multiple experimental setups.
AI.result: Experiments show that different personas reliably steer the ideation into distinct topical domains, that the chosen collaboration mode (separate vs. together vs. separate-then-together) affects the diversity of ideas produced, and that multi-agent, persona-driven setups yield deeper ideas with broader cross-domain coverage compared to baseline configurations.
AI.conclusion: Persona-based agent design and deliberate selection of collaboration dynamics are key levers for improving AI-driven brainstorming. By curating domain-specific personas and structuring how they interact, one can systematically control and enhance the diversity, depth, and cross-domain nature of generated ideas, outperforming undifferentiated single-agent or generic multi-agent approaches.

title: Mitigating Catastrophic Forgetting in Target Language Adaptation of LLMs via Source-Shielded Updates
summary: Expanding the linguistic diversity of instruct large language models (LLMs) is crucial for global accessibility but is often hindered by the reliance on costly specialized target language labeled data and catastrophic forgetting during adaptation. We tackle this challenge under a realistic, low-resource constraint: adapting instruct LLMs using only unlabeled target language data. We introduce Source-Shielded Updates (SSU), a selective parameter update strategy that proactively preserves source knowledge. Using a small set of source data and a parameter importance scoring method, SSU identifies parameters critical to maintaining source abilities. It then applies a column-wise freezing strategy to protect these parameters before adaptation. Experiments across five typologically diverse languages and 7B and 13B models demonstrate that SSU successfully mitigates catastrophic forgetting. It reduces performance degradation on monolingual source tasks to just 3.4% (7B) and 2.8% (13B) on average, a stark contrast to the 20.3% and 22.3% from full fine-tuning. SSU also achieves target-language performance highly competitive with full fine-tuning, outperforming it on all benchmarks for 7B models and the majority for 13B models.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes Source-Shielded Updates (SSU), a selective parameter-freezing strategy that lets instruct LLMs learn new low-resource target languages using only unlabeled target data, while largely avoiding catastrophic forgetting of source-language capabilities and matching or surpassing full fine-tuning on both source and target tasks.
AI.motivation: Instruct LLMs are mostly trained for high-resource languages, limiting global accessibility for speakers of low-resource languages. Extending these models to new languages typically requires costly labeled data and full fine-tuning, which often causes catastrophic forgetting of the original (source-language) instruction-following abilities. The authors aim to develop a realistic adaptation method that uses only unlabeled target-language data yet maintains strong performance in the original language.
AI.method: They introduce Source-Shielded Updates (SSU), a parameter-efficient adaptation technique. First, they use a small set of source-language data to compute an importance score for each parameter with respect to maintaining source abilities. Based on these scores, they ‘shield’ (freeze) important parameters using a column-wise freezing scheme so that they are not updated during adaptation to the new target language. The remaining, less critical parameters are fine-tuned using only unlabeled target-language data. This selective update strategy proactively preserves source knowledge while enabling target-language acquisition.
AI.result: On five typologically diverse target languages and for 7B and 13B-parameter instruct LLMs, SSU dramatically reduces catastrophic forgetting compared to standard full fine-tuning. Average performance degradation on source-language tasks drops to 3.4% for 7B and 2.8% for 13B models, versus 20.3% and 22.3% for full fine-tuning. At the same time, SSU achieves target-language performance that is highly competitive with, and often better than, full fine-tuning: it outperforms full fine-tuning on all target benchmarks for 7B models and on most benchmarks for 13B models.
AI.conclusion: Selective, importance-aware parameter freezing via SSU enables instruct LLMs to acquire new target-language abilities from unlabeled data while largely preserving existing source-language skills. This approach alleviates catastrophic forgetting under realistic low-resource conditions and can be a practical strategy for expanding the linguistic coverage of large language models without sacrificing their original capabilities.

title: A Modular Cognitive Architecture for Assisted Reasoning: The Nemosine Framework
summary: This paper presents the Nemosine Framework, a modular cognitive architecture designed to support assisted reasoning, structured thinking, and systematic analysis. The model operates through functional cognitive modules ("personas") that organize tasks such as planning, evaluation, cross-checking, and narrative synthesis. The framework combines principles from metacognition, distributed cognition, and modular cognitive systems to offer an operational structure for assisted problem-solving and decision support. The architecture is documented through formal specification, internal consistency criteria, and reproducible structural components. The goal is to provide a clear conceptual basis for future computational implementations and to contribute to the study of symbolic-modular architectures for reasoning.

AI.tldr: Introduces the Nemosine Framework, a modular cognitive architecture for assisted reasoning and structured problem-solving.
AI.motivation: There is a need for clear, operational cognitive architectures that can support assisted reasoning, structured thinking, and systematic analysis, especially for complex problem-solving and decision support tasks. Existing approaches may lack clear modular organization, formal specification, or explicit metacognitive structure.
AI.method: Proposes a modular cognitive architecture composed of functional modules or “personas” (for planning, evaluation, cross-checking, narrative synthesis, etc.), grounded in principles of metacognition, distributed cognition, and modular cognitive systems. The paper documents the architecture with formal specifications, internal consistency criteria, and reproducible structural components.
AI.result: Defines and describes the Nemosine Framework, its cognitive modules, their interactions, and the criteria for internal consistency. Provides a structured, reproducible architecture that can be used as a blueprint for future implementations or analyses of symbolic-modular reasoning systems.
AI.conclusion: The Nemosine Framework offers a clear conceptual and structural basis for assisted reasoning and systematic analysis, and serves as a foundational reference for future computational implementations and research on symbolic-modular architectures for reasoning.

title: SEAL: Self-Evolving Agentic Learning for Conversational Question Answering over Knowledge Graphs
summary: Knowledge-based conversational question answering (KBCQA) confronts persistent challenges in resolving coreference, modeling contextual dependencies, and executing complex logical reasoning. Existing approaches, whether end-to-end semantic parsing or stepwise agent-based reasoning, often suffer from structural inaccuracies and prohibitive computational costs, particularly when processing intricate queries over large knowledge graphs. To address these limitations, we introduce SEAL, a novel two-stage semantic parsing framework grounded in self-evolving agentic learning. In the first stage, a large language model (LLM) extracts a minimal S-expression core that captures the essential semantics of the input query. This core is then refined by an agentic calibration module, which corrects syntactic inconsistencies and aligns entities and relations precisely with the underlying knowledge graph. The second stage employs template-based completion, guided by question-type prediction and placeholder instantiation, to construct a fully executable S-expression. This decomposition not only simplifies logical form generation but also significantly enhances structural fidelity and linking efficiency.
